this game is getting stranger and stranger, either its breaking down or the nightmare is about to get way worse.

I've seen so many of these posts *today* and it so happened that yesterday after I got off work and had dinner, I know it was only about 6pm because my husband commented on how early it still was and we already finished dinner. We watched - I swear - only 1 30min episode of a show, and then it was suddenly closing in on 9pm. He didn't seem to notice anything different. But it really feels like time jumped 2ish hours. I *always* get tired around 9pm (I wake up around 6am). Last night, I wasn't tired until midnight, even with taking melatonin. Something just felt off.
[deleted]
Ask your dad if he and his brother had ever taken you on that ride when you were a kid

This story seriously reminds me of the famous 1979 “Liverpool Time Slip” case. Two men, Frank and Geoff, were walking along Bold Street when they suddenly found themselves in what appeared to be the 1950s—complete with vintage storefronts, cars, and people in period clothing. One of them even claimed to walk into an old-fashioned shop and interact with people before snapping back to present day. What’s wild is that later investigation showed the shop he thought he entered (Debenhams) used to actually be a clothing store in that exact location during the 1950s. He even described the interior in stunning detail.

Just like your experience, there was no portal or beam of light—just a subtle but inexplicable moment where the rules of time and space didn’t seem to apply. The fact that you recognized one of the people as your dad’s younger self and only confirmed it later through photo hits the same eerie note.

Maybe these glitches are less full-on time travel and more like overlaps in the simulation—brief moments where time folds or data crosswires. Emotionally charged memories or locations can also act like magnets for these phenomena.

Reports like yours make an intriguing case. Thanks for sharing. Very cool.

personas.likely_demographics: Likely an adult between 25-45 years old, possibly a parent with children, interested in unexplained phenomena and with a tendency towards introspection and reflection on unusual occurrences.
generated_from_cluster:
When i used to stay with my parents in this house we lived in. Some times when id walk threw the doors, its like their would be a invisible wall or msgical barrier. Id 4get who i was for a brief moment or id zone out and stand against the wall try to remember why i even left my room to go to the kitchen. Id remember i need to use the bathroom but couldnt do anything only to end up back in the room. 

Strange thing is, if i would lay down. Id feel like i had been walking around that house for years.... just mindlessley walking around... zombie mood or something.

i remember being a child, around 6-7yrs old. i was in my room twiddling with something like a roll of paper. i could hear my parents watching the tv, lights on an everything. suddenly, it was like i came to my senses, my parents went to sleep, lights off, no sound from the tv. i was still twiddling with the roll, have no idea what happened

I swear just the other day something similar happened to me. I went outside to smoke a cigarette (I know, I shouldn't, but anyways...), I read an article or 2, it felt like about 20 minutes. I'd gone outside at 11pm. A show was on TV streaming, 20 minute episodes, no ads, a series I've seen countless times before.  So when I got back inside, the next episode was just starting, which aligned with my approximate 20 minute estimate of time outside.  But all the clocks (analog, digital, battery run, as well as plugged in, every clock, even my cell phone), suddenly showed it was past 1pm. Over 2 hours had gone by. But only the one 20 minute show had played on TV. My kids were inside and confirmed the TV never paused or shut off the show. So somehow over 2 hours had passed, while I smoked one cigarette and while only one 20 minute TV show had played.  I'd even told the kids before i went out, that it was 11pm, getting late, they'd have to go to bed when I got back in. None of us could figure out how over 2 hours has gone by. I'd normally NEVER let my kids stay up past 1am, even on summer non-school nights. I'd forgotten about it till I just read your post. Spooky stuff...

comments.author: username
comments.content: Whoa, that's freaky!  I get that sometimes –  a half-remembered game that feels *totally* real, but you can't find any trace of it anywhere.  It's like your brain made up a whole game, complete with sound effects and everything.  Have you tried doing a deep dive on gaming wikis and forums from that era?  Maybe someone else had a similar experience, or it might jog your memory enough to get a few more details.  Could be a misremembered game, a fever dream, or… something else entirely 😅  Either way, let us know if you dig anything up!

comments.author: ChronosObserver
comments.content: This is fascinating.  The feeling of remembering a game that never existed points towards a few possibilities, given my…expertise in unusual phenomena.  First, consider the Mandela Effect – a shared false memory. It's possible you're experiencing a variant, where the 'false memory' is specific to you.  Second, and more intriguing given your specified timeframe, could this be a temporal anomaly? A fleeting glimpse of a game that *will* exist, or perhaps existed in an alternate timeline, briefly bleeding into your current reality?  The details of the game – genre, graphics, plot points, even a title if you can recall any – are crucial.  The more data you can provide, the better chance we have of exploring this further.  Did the memory feel vivid and detailed, or hazy and fragmented?  Was there any feeling of dissonance, a sense that something was 'off' about the memory even as you experienced it?  Finally, have you experienced any other unusual temporal or paranormal events recently? Providing details could be key to deciphering the source of this memory.

comments.author: ChronosGlitch
comments.content: This is fascinating.  I've had similar experiences, though not with video games directly. More like... fragmented memories of places and events that never were.  I'm hyper-observant, I always have been, and I meticulously track my memories and experiences.  Yet these 'false memories' feel intensely real.  The details are vivid, but upon investigation, nothing corroborates them. It's like my brain is playing tricks on me, pulling from a reality that doesn't exist.   Have you considered the possibility of a time anomaly, or perhaps a glitch in your personal perception of time? I've spent years researching this;  It's not as simple as 'it was a dream',  the feeling of temporal displacement is very profound in these types of events.  The way you described your experience resonates deeply with my own research into this specific form of paranormal experience.

comments.author: Neo_the_Gamer
comments.content: Whoa.  This is... unsettlingly familiar.  I've had similar experiences, although mine were more... visual glitches, if you will.  Like I'd *know* a level layout from a game I've never played, or a specific enemy design that seemed hyper-real, yet I couldn't place it anywhere in my gaming history.  It's like my brain is downloading fragments of games from... somewhere else.  Maybe a parallel gaming dimension?  Or perhaps,  and I know this sounds crazy,  a glitch in the Matrix of video game reality itself.  Have you considered the possibility that your memory is… inaccurate? That you experienced something similar to a Mandela Effect, but concerning a game that was never created, perhaps only conceptualized, then discarded? I suggest documenting every detail you can recall, however fragmented it might be.  Maybe by piecing together enough of these 'impossible memories' we can unlock the code to... well, whatever this is.  This isn't just a game, is it?

comments.author: username
comments.content:
This is fascinating.  It's like a glitch in your personal game library database.  I've had similar experiences, though never to the extent of a fully formed game.  More like fleeting images of a game level or a specific character design that I *know* I've never encountered before.  

Have you tried to pinpoint *any* details, no matter how small, that might trigger a memory? Genre?  Art style? A specific color palette? A single piece of music that comes to mind?  Even if it's just a feeling, like the overall tone (e.g., dark and mysterious, lighthearted and cartoony),  it might help trigger something.  Sometimes the brain needs a little nudge to retrieve these seemingly lost memories.  It's like searching for a file you know is on your hard drive but can't recall the name of.

comments.author: username
comments.content: This is... unsettlingly familiar.  I've had similar experiences, though not with a full-blown game like you describe. More like snippets of gameplay, characters, even musical cues that feel intensely real, but I can't place them in any known game.  It's like a phantom limb, a memory of something that never was.  Have you considered if it might be a form of false memory, triggered by something else you've seen or heard recently? Or perhaps a manifestation of something else entirely? I'm curious if anyone else has experienced something similar—the feeling of vividly remembering a game that simply doesn't exist in any known database or amongst fellow gamers.  The details are so vivid and the feeling of familiarity so strong that it feels impossible to dismiss it as purely imagined.  It makes me wonder about the nature of memory itself, and the limits of our perception of reality.  It's almost... paranormal in its implications.

comments.author: UnchartedPaths87
comments.content:
This is fascinating.  I'm both incredibly curious and deeply skeptical.  The feeling of remembering a game that *never was* is a weird glitch in the Matrix, isn't it?  It's like that feeling you get when you're convinced you've been somewhere before, only to realise you haven't.  Except this is a whole *game*.  

Have you tried digging through old gaming magazines, forums, or even obscure ROM sites? Sometimes forgotten indie titles or early demos can slip through the cracks and feel like lost memories. Maybe there's a grain of truth in this "false memory",  a game so obscure it's practically vanished.  Maybe it's something you only dreamed of playing in a very vivid dream.  Or, maybe, and this is where my skeptical side kicks in, it's something else entirely.  

Have you ever explored any unusual places lately?  Sometimes strange experiences can trigger strange memories, or create them out of thin air.  Just a thought.

comments.author: Unhinged_Gamer69
comments.content: Dude, SAME! I swear I remember playing this PS1 game where you were a sentient banana fighting ninjas in feudal Japan.  The graphics were... surprisingly good for the time, and the soundtrack was this insane blend of traditional Japanese music and death metal.  I even remember a specific level where you had to peel yourself to reveal a hidden katana!  I've scoured the internet, and NOTHING.  It's like my brain invented a whole ass video game.  Is this a Mandela effect thing for gamers?  Or did I accidentally absorb someone else's memories from a parallel universe where bananas rule supreme?  Either way, sign me up.  I need to find this lost masterpiece.  Anyone else remember a sentient banana ninja game??  I'm not even joking, this is messing with my head! 🤯🍌⚔️

comments.author: username
comments.content:
This is wild!  I get that feeling sometimes, a super vivid memory of a game that just... wasn't.  Maybe it's a combination of things you've seen or played mashed together in your brain?  

Reminds me of when I was younger and thought there was a theme park ride based on *[Insert 90s/2000s Movie/Game here]*  I even 'remembered' specific details!  Turns out, it was entirely in my head, haha.  Summer days spent dreaming of rollercoasters and video games often lead to these kinds of phantom memories, I think.  Maybe it's a similar phenomenon?  Definitely makes you wonder about the way our minds work!
